the biggest thing about running for a presidential election is your campaign. raise a few million dollars by any means necessary, and start running ads. of course your ads are not gonna talk about what you plan to do to make the country run smoother (apparently the public doesnt care about that). instead, you work on the public's emotions. create feelings of anger in them toward your opponent, and feelings of heroic buddy-ness in them toward yourself. here are some key points for getting the fickle public to like you coming close to elections:
 
 - show clips of your opponent frowning, looking confused or doing something goofy. then show clips of yourself shaking hands, signing autographs or being cheered on by supporters
 
 - show clips of your opponent cavorting or enjoying luxury of some sort, and then clips of yourself in a nature-oriented environment or chatting with regular-looking people
 
 - talk about the wild and stupid events of your opponent's childhood and youth, then contrast it to your uneventful and pure upbringing (if you dont have a pure unbringing, then just leave that out and say you didnt do those things that your opponent did)
 
 - show clips of the opponent making promises that he never kept even though he emphasised that he actually keeps his promises, then make those same promises, emphasising that youll actually keep them
 
 - try to conceal the sources of your campaign funds, then do your best to expose how unscrupulous your opponent was in raising his campaign money
 
 - incorporate serene scapes (sunsets, children playing, flowers, puppies, etc) into your campaign ads, and play soothing instrumentals, like harps or piano solos in the background
 
 - finally, never ever ever ever ever talk about the issues. nobody cares that your opponent made a disaster of his political past (unless its a sex scandal). and nobody cares whether youre a competent decision maker and leader. and nobody cares if you plan to continue governing EXACTLY how the other guy was, or that your radical changes are gonna make the country better or worse. people dont like to think, they just like to feel. so emotional ping-pong is the only way to get their votes. it always has worked and it always will

Ah, but who's fault is this?
 
 In a recent letter to the editor, a woman compained that candidate FOO (could be either one) hadn't said anything about medicare, which was important to her. In fact, both candidates have said quite alot about medicare. They've made speeches, and their web sites have fairly detailed positions outlined. She had just put zero effort into doing any research. There are simply too many people out there who don't want to put any effort into finding things out. They want to be told, preferably in a 30 second sound bite, what to think. If the only thing that people pay attention to is content free blurbs, then you can't really blame the politicians for giving it to them.

 i think the media is prone to show what the candidates tell them to show, for the right price. and as long as the ads have that little disclaimer that says "paid for by the supporters of X" then it shouldnt be a problem of whether the media censors or allows it. the issues arent covered because the media plays the same games as the politicians: they play on emotions. if its a story to make you cower in fear, buy more protection, or becoming more paranoid about their surroundings, then the media endorses it. emotion is a better rein to steer the public than intellect and thought.
 
 if you ever get hold of a campaign budget, i'll bet youll find that the majority of funds goes on staged tv ads and fired up rallies and tours. a politician wants to look like a champion and a revolutionary at election time, not a wise and sober decision maker and thinker (even though when the election is over, thats when we all start to think about how stupid/rash/thoughtless/passive/apathetic our leader is...)
